review.title: Context Trees: Augmenting Geospatial Trajectories with Context
review.abstract: Exposing latent knowledge in geospatial trajectories has the potential to provide a better understanding of the movements of individuals and groups. Motivated by such a desire, this work presents the context tree, a new hierarchical data structure that summarises the context behind user actions in a single model. We propose a method for context tree construction that augments geospatial trajectories with land usage data to identify such contexts. Through evaluation of the construction method and analysis of the properties of generated context trees, we demonstrate the foundation for understanding and modelling behaviour afforded. Summarising user contexts into a single data structure gives easy access to information that would otherwise remain latent, providing the basis for better understanding and predicting the actions and behaviours of individuals and groups. Finally, we also present a method for pruning context trees, for use in applications where it is desirable to reduce the size of the tree while retaining useful information.

metadata.title: Context Trees: Augmenting Geospatial Trajectories with Context

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The representation of the latent knowledge present in geospatial trajectories has become an increasingly important research topic in recent years, in part due to the proliferation of location-based hardware and the resulting availability of trajectory data. Motivated by the desire to understand users "movement patterns, this paper presents a new data structure, the context tree, which summarizes the context behind users" actions in a single hierarchical model. Furthermore, the paper proposes a method for generating context trees from geospatial trajectories and land use information, and provides concrete implementations for each stage of the method, namely augmentation, filtering and clustering. A context tree itself consists of clusters on multiple scales describing the contexts in which the user was immersed, a simple collection of information that would have previously remained hidden, and forms the basis for understanding and predicting the actions and behaviors of groups and individuals.

sections.heading: 2.1 Geospatial Datasets
sections.text: Although it is becoming increasingly easier to collect geographical data due to the proliferation of smartphones DC 8uket 2009, the availability of public geographical data sets still poses a challenge for researchers. Privacy concerns are the main obstacle to making such data publicly available, and as a result, there are only a limited number of public data sets, each of which has some drawbacks. To overcome these problems, many researchers have collected data for their own work [Ashbrook and Starner, 2003; Si la-Nowicka et al., 2015; Thomason et al., 2015a]. However, the use of such private data sets reduces the reproducibility of work, and thus the use of public data is preferred. Such publicly available data sets include the Reality Mining datasets of MIT [Eagle and Sandy Pentland, 2005], which uses cell towers to estimate the locations of devices belonging to 100 students.

sections.heading: 2.2 Investigative Techniques
sections.text: For many techniques related to the extraction of knowledge from data, the collection of a concrete basic truth is not feasible. A significant location determination, for example, can extract places on different scales and therefore there cannot be a single basic truth. Existing literature addresses this by examining the properties of the results of such techniques and comparing these properties with expected results. Thus, Guidotti et al. [2015] create synthetic trajectories with known properties and develop metrics to compare extracted places with desirable properties. Thomason et al. [2015a] compare properties of the identified places with acceptable ranges of values derived from the knowledge of the input data, as well as the applicability of the technique using examples. For classification in travel mode, Si laNowicka et al. [2015] compare the results with a small group of manually labeled subtrajectories. In order to cope with the limited availability of user-defined truths, we can present the results as a partial assessment of both the proposed algorithms and the proposed results.

sections.heading: 3 Proposed Structure: The Context Tree
sections.text: This paper proposes and evaluates the hierarchical data structure of the context tree, which summarizes the contexts a user is immersed in at multiple levels. Each leaf node of the tree represents a real feature or element with which the user is likely to have interacted, be it a specific building, area, or individual feature (e.g. a bank in a park). These individual elements are connected by context nodes that represent a context on a particular scale, where the time the user has spent within a context is likely to have had similar goals or goals, and is identified by exploring the time the user spends with elements with similar properties or elements that are interacted with in a similar way. By summarizing time in this way, the context tree can become the basis for understanding people from augmented geospatial data. The context structure is presented in Figure 1.

sections.heading: 1. Inputs
sections.text: The raw geographical trajectories and land use data are fed into the system.

sections.heading: 2. Augmentation
sections.text: Land use elements likely to have interacted with are identified by extracting and filtering all potential elements to remove noise.

sections.heading: 3. Clustering
sections.text: Filtered land use elements and their interactions become the basis for context-dependent clustering. Clustering is achieved using a hierarchical agglomeration algorithm.

sections.heading: 4. Representation
sections.text: Once the elements are bundled, they form a structure of context tree data that can be used as a basis for further understanding the behavior of individuals and groups.

sections.heading: 5. Pruning
sections.text: Some applications may be limited by the amount of data they can store or process, and therefore it may be necessary to prune a context tree in order to reduce its size while obtaining as much useful information as possible. Intersection is achieved by analyzing the nodes of a context tree in terms of a defined number of metrics. In the following sections, we describe the stages of augmentation (Section 4), clustering (Section 5), representation (Section 5) and retrospection (Section 7) in detail.

sections.heading: 4 Trajectory Augmentation
sections.text: In order to better understand users by their previous actions, and assuming that only geographical data is available at the time the data is collected, this section describes the process of augmenting the trajectory, combining raw trajectories with area usage data. A trajectory is a temporal sequence of data points that locate a person or entity: T = (p1, p2, p3,..., pn), where pi = {ti, li, ai} is an individual trajectory point consisting of time (ti), place (li, e.g. a < lat, lng > pair) and accuracy (ai, typically measured in meters). In addition to such trajectories, land usage data may also be used to identify locations and entities that are significant to the user. Land usage data are viewed as sets of units with associated information. In this case, a unit directly represents an object, characteristic, or area, e.g. a postcard, a unit, or field, the land usage data is considered to be combined into a residential unit or a residential unit.

sections.heading: 4.1 Element Extraction
sections.text: The process of obtaining relevant land use elements is illustrated in Figure 3. A raw geological trajectory (Step 1) is superimposed on a land use dataset (Step 2), using the accuracy recorded by a positioning device (e.g. GPS, measured in meters) (Step 3), so that all elements that are fully or partially within the radius are stored next to the original trajectory point (Step 4). This process is automatically completed by iterating through each trajectory point and queriing the land use dataset for each element that intersects or covers part of the radius of accuracy.

sections.heading: 4.2 Filtering
sections.text: Since the element extraction method (Section 4.1) extends the trajectories with all land use elements that are within the accuracy radius of a trajectory point, it tends to record a significant number of elements with which the user has not interacted. To cope with these noise elements, a filtering method can be used. Our proposed filter is a generalized version of a weighted average filter, a technique typically used to smooth out noisy signals, modified to work across sets of land use elements and shown in Figure 4. The filter receives a Bu filter of elements and selects from this Bu filter based on an assigned weight in a three-step process: 1. A Bu filter of points and associated land use data is selected. 2. Land use elements in the Bu filter are weighted and evaluated. 3. Elements are selected based on their inclusion in the output.

sections.text: When each element in the bus is assigned a score, the selection can be made either by using a fixed threshold to discard low-score elements, or by limiting all elements to their score by using soft thresholds. Soft threshold is a technique commonly used in signal processing where a core is applied to the calculated scores, bringing higher values closer to 1 and lower values closer to 0. While soft threshold eliminates the need to apply a fixed threshold, this work is only about whether or not an element is included in the output set, and therefore we use a threshold, t, where each element with a normal score is greater than t part of the output set and the remaining elements are discarded.

sections.heading: 4.3 Data Summarisation
sections.text: Once filtered, advanced trajectories contain a record of where a person was at a given time, along with the real characteristics with which they were likely to interact. These interactions are summarized into continuous periods of time, taking into account each land-use element encountered. If the same land-use unit is associated with two consecutive points, it can be assumed that it is also associated with the period between these points, if such a period is clearly small. An example summary is shown in Figure 4 (right). If the time between two consecutive points is large, it cannot be determined whether the user has stopped interacting with an element and resumed before the next occurrence of data collection, and thus a time limit between two consecutive points associated with the same element is given as tmax. If the time between two consecutive points is greater than tmax, then the interactions are split, a technique that can also be used in applications for location extraction of 2016, Montoason, 2010 and Thomatica, during Perez.

sections.heading: 5 Contextual Clustering
sections.text: The identification of similar contexts takes place through clustering, which takes into account both the characteristics of the elements and the characteristics of the user interactions in order to identify similarities. Rather than aiming to identify a single level of clusters that would limit the usefulness and applicability of the clusters to a single scale, the goal here is to build a hierarchical model that is built by gradually merging land-use elements that represent similar contexts in a context tree, the representation of which was previously shown in Figure 1.

sections.heading: 5.3 Hierarchical Clustering
sections.text: While traditional clustering is limited in that it extracts clusters on a single scale, which may not be suitable for a particular task, hierarchical clustering identifies clusters on multiple scales. We use a greedy hierarchical agglomerative cluster algorithm introduced in Algorithm 2, which extracts clusters of increasing similarity up to a single root node, creating a context tree. While the hierarchical agglomerative cluster algorithm itself is fairly standard, its application to context tree generation is new; the algorithm differs slightly from existing hierarchical cluster approaches by being able to extract multiple clusters in a single step when they are at the same distance.

sections.heading: 6 Evaluation and Results
sections.text: In this paper, it is not feasible to obtain a concrete reason truth to serve as a comparison point for the evaluation, because the accuracy of an extracted set of clusters depends on the task for which the clusters are used. In view of this, we choose to evaluate the proposed techniques using an approach similar to those followed in the existing literature, where there is not a single soil-related truth, as discussed in Section 2.2. This is achieved by examining the properties of the generated context trees and comparing them with expected results, while providing small, representative examples demonstrating the effectiveness of a section shown by these procedures. This section evaluates the proposed context tree data structure, along with the production method proposed in Sections 4 and 5. Although there are many use cases for context trees, including as a basis for anomaly detection, location prediction and urban planning, we focus on understanding the high-level behavior of a single tree during a 24-hour representative example.

sections.heading: 6.1 Data
sections.text: The trajectories used are taken from the Nokia Mobile Data Challenge (MDC) Dataset [Kiukkonen et al., 2010; Laurila et al., 2012] as discussed in Section 2.1. From this dataset, we select the data from the real world of 40 users with the largest number of tractor points for this evaluation. While this dataset contains an enormous amount of information, we only consider the timestamp, width, length and accuracy of each data point (in line with the discussion in Section 4). In addition, and for comparative purposes, we also select 5 users from the GeoLife Dataset [Zheng et al., 2008a, 2009, 2010] for evaluation. While the MDC Dataset aims to provide continuous coordinates for users, the GeoLife data are only periods in which users moved.

sections.heading: 6.2 Filtering
sections.text: This section evaluates and characterizes the performance of the filter on real data by first examining how the element weights are distributed and then showing how this affects the elements of land use that are filtered. Filtering takes two parameters: and t. The parameter specifies the width of the filter process, in seconds, and t specifies a threshold at which elements with a calculated weight greater than t form the output set. Holding = 1200, Figure 8 shows the distribution of weights for all elements in the filter process (i.e. the values of NormalisedScore from Eq.2) for all 11,575 track points belonging to a sample MDC user. The e-effects of t (with = 1200) and (with t = 0.8) on the average number of elements per point after filtering can be seen in Figures 9a and 9b.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 Filtering Characterisation
sections.text: To better understand the filtering process, we examine the properties of the filtered data, focusing in particular on how the elements and their semantics change. The aim of filtering is to remove noise and focus the data on elements with which the user is likely to have interacted at a particular time. It is therefore reasonable to assume that the elements after filtering should be more similar than before, with less variation caused by the inclusion of random elements. To investigate this hypothesis, Figure 11 shows the average similarity of the key elements (i.e. only the key part of the "key: value" pair that makes up the tags of an element of a broad type, such as "buildings") both before and after filtering for a particular user over 1000 points of its data. This shows that in most cases the similarity of the key elements is increased and the variance significantly reduced after filtering has occurred, indicating that the elements after filtering have been removed are more similar and not related to the filtering elements.

sections.heading: 6.3 Summarising Data
sections.text: Once the data has been filtered, it is summarized in continuous periods of time. Only one parameter, tmax, is needed to specify the maximum time span (in seconds) between consecutive points so that it can be considered contiguous. Figure 12a, using the parameters = 1200 and t = 0.8, shows how tmax a affects the number of such extracted periods, and Figure 12b, showing how tmax a affects the average length of such periods. Figures 12a and 12b show that increasing tmax leads to fewer but longer periods of time being extracted. In the rest of this paper, we use tmax = 1200 (i.e. 20 minutes) because it provides enough time for a user to have stopped interacting with an element and resumed later, without splitting too many interactions unnecessarily.

sections.heading: 7 Context Tree Pruning
sections.text: When context trees are fully stored, the maximum amount of information is retained, but there are applications where reducing the size of a tree may be desirable. Memory-limited devices may, for example, be better able to use a reduced context tree, as this would require lower memory requirements and also allow faster searches due to the smaller number of nodes. In addition, reducing the size of context trees can have application-specific benefits, such as preventing revision when learning predictive models. In both cases, it is desirable to trim the tree to reduce the amount of stored data while obtaining as much information as possible. In this section, a method for such a cut is presented that requires additional processing to select nodes that can be removed, but produces smaller context trees that require less space and fewer operations. Figure 25 provides a representation of a trimmed context tree.

sections.heading: 7.1 Pruning Criteria
sections.text: Each cluster is considered with the null hypothesis, and the hypothesis is rejected if the benefit of storing the cluster exceeds a threshold. Any cluster for which we cannot reject the hypothesis is truncated, and its parent is marked as prunable. As there are no metrics for this task yet, we adapt existing metrics that are used in related areas for the purpose of truncating context trees.

sections.heading: 7.1.1 Storage Cost
sections.text: To determine the cost of storing a cluster, it is important to understand how clusters are built in a context tree (described in Section 5.1). When two clusters are merged into a parent cluster, the aspects that belong to each cluster are looked at one by one; in particular, the tags, times, and coordinate sets. Sets of tags are combined from the parent clusters by incorporating their association, while times and coordinate sets are merged in a way that combines overlapping components into individual elements, and thus, by combining child clusters into a parent cluster, information is removed. Thus, the cost of storing an additional node is the cost of storing the individual components (e.g. time range) that exist in a child but are not present in the same form in its parent part.

sections.heading: 7.1.2 Cluster Utility
sections.text: Determining the benefit of a cluster is cult and depends on the specific use of the context tree. Therefore, any application of the approach must take into account the goal of cutting and use that goal to inform the measurement of the benefit of a particular cluster. We choose a general approach that can be tailored to specific needs by providing a measure of the lost information when the parent of a cluster is used to represent the child, similar to the Kullback-Leibler divergence used to measure the divergence between probability distributions. Since parents contain a superset of children, we consider the benefit of a cluster of children (C) vis-à-vis its parent (P) to be the percentage of information available to the parent that is not covered by the child, with the measure of information taking into account the attributes (i.e. tags, times, and coordinate sets) that are present in each cluster: Information (C) = P t2times duration () + Cordarea (if the Cordarea) and Cordarea (Cordarea) (i.e.

sections.text: Pruning requires a prefabricated context tree and two parameters, namely "and," where "represents a threshold for pruning, and" is a penalty associated with each node in calculating its storage costs. Figure 26 shows that the number of nodes in a context tree can be dramatically reduced if a context tree is pruned that is generated from the same data and parameters as those used in Figure 17, with "0.5" and "1." From this figure, it is possible to see that the number of nodes in a context tree can be drastically reduced while most of the information is retained. Selected trees = 0.6, the resulting pruned context tree contains about 20% of the nodes present in the unpruned tree, but retains nearly 70% of the useful information. While the process of pruning the context tree adds additional complexity, the resulting tree is considerably more compact, and thus have applications that require pruning or re-pruning the same tree, requiring only one application at a time.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: The Context Tree is a novel data structure that provides quick access to summary information on a user's interactions with their environment, providing a basis for further analysis, understanding and modelling of the behavior of individuals and groups. Furthermore, this work has provided an analysis of the two context trees and the associated generational process, in addition to a proposed method for pruning context trees that requires less processing and storage for further applications. Data used for the evaluation comes from the publicly available MDC [Kiukkonen et al., 2010; Laurila et al.] and GeoLife [Zheng et al.].

metadata.abstractText: Exposing latent knowledge in geospatial trajectories has the potential to provide a better understanding of the movements of individuals and groups. Motivated by such a desire, this work presents the context tree, a new hierarchical data structure that summarises the context behind user actions in a single model. We propose a method for context tree construction that augments geospatial trajectories with land usage data to identify such contexts. Through evaluation of the construction method and analysis of the properties of generated context trees, we demonstrate the foundation for understanding and modelling behaviour a↵orded. Summarising user contexts into a single data structure gives easy access to information that would otherwise remain latent, providing the basis for better understanding and predicting the actions and behaviours of individuals and groups. Finally, we also present a method for pruning context trees, for use in applications where it is desirable to reduce the size of the tree while retaining useful information.
